titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr: Arbuthnot called on me this forenoon and sat about half an hour.— Did not go this Evening to the Opera—pass’d it mostly at home—and the latter part of it at Dr: Brown’s.— Lord Talbot—Mr: and Mrs: Errington, and Mr: Sloper there—and finally Mr: Garlike— The Doctor called to Countess Panin, who has a daughter— Weather very cold again.

2. Read Lessing’s life of Plautus, and critique upon his plays. He affirms the Captives to be the most admirable Comedy that ever was brought upon the Stage.— I am not of his opinion.— At home all day and Evening. Mr: and Mrs: Errington here in the Evening.— Did not go to the Assembly which was at the Princess de Sacken’s.— Read some of the poems of Hamilton.

3. Snowed all the morning.— Walk however in the park.— Evening at the Queen’s Court, in full ceremony again.— Played whist with the Swedish Ladies Countess Piper, and Madame Armfeldt, and Coll: Zastrow.— Mrs: Adams stayed to supper.

4. At Mr: Schickler’s Counting house this morning.— Settling accounts.— Evening at the Opera. Armida again— The next representation is to be the last.— Reading the 23d: vol: of Lessing: several small essays upon theatrical subjects.— Madame Necker’s works.— A few very ingenious and valuable remarks—many indifferent, and many ridiculous, and absurd, together with frequent repetitions.
5. Busied in writing this forenoon. Miss Brown at tea and part of the Evening, which we spent altogether at home— Reading Lessing’s Observations upon the Tragedies which go under the name of Seneca.
6. Snow—and again excessively cold.— Short walk only— The day idly spent— Reading Lessing in the morning and Madame Necker in the Evening. Mrs: Adams, Evening at Doctor Brown’s.
7. As the carnaval draws towards its end, we begin to have a little more time to ourselves.— This Evening at Doctor Brown’s— Played chess with him.— Wrote a couple of short Letters.
8. The weather has again been extremely cold these two days.— All day and Evening at home excepting a walk in the park.— Read the 11th. book of Paradise lost.

9. Did not go to the Assembly— The weather being still excessively cold.— Walking met Mr: Garlike. Mrs: Adams pass’d a couple of hours in the Evening with Mrs: Errington— Began reading the 24th: volume of Lessing’s works; containing the Hamburg Dramaturgy.— Fruitless labour in the Evening.

10. Rose late— Madame Necker, says that by studying a language a quarter of an hour every day, one will make some progress in attaining it— I study German between two and three hours at least every day, and make scarcely any progress. Mrs: Errington & Bell Brown to spend the Evening.

11. Weather at length has moderated. Mr: Livingston and Mr: Arbuthnot at tea, and great part of the Evening.— Arbuthnot has no esteem for the modern writers of Latin.— Read the conclusion of the New Bath Guide.—

12. Mrs: Adams’s birth day.— Mrs: Errington and the Miss Brown’s spent the Evening here.— Doctor Brown called.— Continued reading Lessing’s Hamburg Dramaturgy— He delights to seize every opportunity of criticising Voltaire.

13. The carnaval closed this Evening, with a Redoute, in which a splendid quadrille was performed, by the Queen. The English Prince Augustus, and most of the persons of both sexes belonging to the Court. The idea, was to represent the nuptials of Philip 2. of Spain, with Mary Queen of England.— The Queen took the part of Mary; and Prince Augustus that of Philip— The dresses were all in the highest style of magnificence, and partly conformable to the usual dresses of that time—English, Spanish, Flemish, Scots and Mexicans. But the Ladies could not adopt the dress of the period so far as to cover their bosoms.— The Queen first entered on one side of the house, with her suite, and after walking round the pit; of took her stand. Philip and his attendants then came in from the other side, and after a like procession took his stand opposite to the Queen— The Quadrille was then danced by the whole company, after which the two parties joined in a procession, walked round the Hall, and came into the Royal box.— The whole was over in half an hour, and began, a little before 11 o’clock.— We had been waiting for it from 1/2 past eight.— The place was then opened to the usual Masks and Dominos of a Redoute.— We came home at about one.

14. Snowy weather— At home all day.— Finished my translations from Gellert, which take too much time for a mere exercise— Mrs: Adams at Mrs: Browns in the Evening. Called there for a few minutes myself— Count Bruhl and his family— Lord Talbot and Mr: Sloper there.— Read in the 3d: volume of Madame Necker’s Melanges.

15. Walk’d in the Park.— Remainder of the day and Evening at home— Miss Neale here in the Evening Began the 4th: volume of Gillies’s History of Greece, and in German the 25th: volume of Lessing and second of the Hamburg Dramaturgy.

16. Wrote a short Letter to Mr: Murray— I am spending my time in a manner that I can hardly answer to myself— In a sort of literary luxury, that very much resembles idleness.— Evening at Count Haugwitz’s, where the Wednesday and Saturday parties suspended by the Carnaval, were again renewed. Played Whist, with Madam de Reck, Madam de Zastrow, and Mr: Sydow. Did not stay to supper. Mrs: Adams passed the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s.
17. Weather very much moderated.— Walk in the park.— Reading Lessing’s dramatical criticisms. Madame Necker’s Melanges, and Gillies’s Grecian History, all at once; besides some pages of Gellert.

18. Spent almost the whole of this day in reading.— Finished the volumes of Madame Necker, and sent them home to Mr: Arbuthnot— Upon the whole they have been very amusing.— They consist of Letters; characters, anecdotes, and detached thoughts of her own, and the friends with whom she associated; with an unfinished Eulogy of Madame de Sevigné.— The Letters are indifferent— Stiff, formal, and full of the pedantry of Politeness.— Some of the thoughts ingenious and just—many of them inaccurate and many absurd— She thinks herself often at the bottom, when she is only beyond her depth. She is peculiarly unfortunate when she draws general conclusions from particular facts; and she never fails to shew her ignorance when she attempts to display learning.— The character of Mr: Necker, is beyond measure ridiculous— Read likewise this Evening the Prologue to Chaucer’s Canterbury tales.— This is the beginning of a plan for reading to Mrs: A the whole collection of the British Poets.

19. Dr: Brown and his family. Lord Talbot, Mr: and Mrs: Errington, Mr: Arbuthnot, and Mr: Sloper dined with us.— Most of them stayed great part of the Evening.— Played chess with Dr: Brown.— Three mails at length came in from Holland— The weather so bad that I did not go out at all.

20. Weather much moderated— Received at length a note from the Ministers of the Cabinet, with a copy of their full powers, and a projet for a Treaty.— Finished this morning Lessing’s Hamburg Dramaturgy, and began upon his literary correspondence—vol 26. of his works. I have derived entertainment and instruction from his dramatic criticisms.— His partiality for the English, and against the French writers is perhaps carried rather too far.— He holds that the Poetics of Aristotle, are a work as perfect and infallible as the Geometry of Euclid.— That the English tragic writers, and especially Shakespeare adhere much more closely to the essential rules of Antiquity than the French, particularly Corneille.— That the latter by observing the letter have altogether departed from the spirit of the Grecian laws prescribing the unities, both of time and place, and that they are very far from attaining the great object of Tragedy, namely to purify the passions by exciting fear and pity compassion.— Among other things he gives an extensive analysis of a Spanish Tragedy, called the Earl of Essex; a very wild and extravagant thing indeed— The first scene of his Emilia Galotti, is evidently imitated from a passage in this play.— Read Gillies after dinner and in the Evening part of the Knight’s tale in Chaucer.

21. Engaged all the morning, upon the plan for a Treaty.— Short walk— Read after dinner in the 4th: vol. of Gillies— It is rather more interesting than those which preceded it— Evening at Dr: Brown’s— Played Whist with him, Mr: Cohen and Mr: Richards.

22. Continued all the morning, working upon the Treaty.— Finished after dinner the Knight’s tale, of Chaucer, and read the Miller’s prologue.— Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Played whist with Madame de Grappendorf, Mlle: de Hagen and Mr: ——— Did not stay to supper.

23. Employed all the morning so busily upon the Treaty, that I lost my usual walk.— Took it however after dinner.— Short letter to Mr: Murray.— Evening a ball given by the Queen; it being the Princess Henry’s birth day.— Madame de Prittwitz was seized the evening before last with an apoplectic fit, as she was playing at cards with Princess Henry—she was too ill to be removed from the house; and expired in it this morning at about ten.— The Princess however did not on that account miss the ball.— Whist with Madame de Reck, the Baron de Taube, and Count Redern.— Was introduced to Mr: Grenville.— Came home before supper.

24. Employed as much of my time this forenoon as I could command upon the Treaty; besides the usual occupation of the day.— Evening at Mr: Cohen’s— Mrs: Brown and her daughter’s there— Played chess with Mr: Cohen— He is very strong.

25. Finished Lessing’s 26th: volume— It consists altogether of critical reviews in periodical publications about the years 1758 and 1759.— Finished this forenoon my first draught for a Treaty.— Called at Nicolaï’s book store for the Prussian Code of Laws.— Dined at Count Panin’s with a company of about thirty persons, chiefly English.— Had some conversation with the Marquis de Lucchesini— Evening at home, reading Chaucer’s tales of the Reeve and Miller.

26. Read in the second volume of Lessing his observation upon the fabulists.— They are the unshapen materials for a work which he designed, but never completed— This is the case of a large part of this collection. Wrote the first draught of a Note to the Cabinet Ministers upon the subject of the Treaty.— Visit from
Mr: Bollman.— In the evening read Gillies and the Cook’s, and Man of Law’s tales in Chaucer. The last is a very good one, and enforces well an excellent moral; that of not being too much elated in prosperity, nor too much depressed in adversity.

27. Began the third volume of Lessing, and read his defence of Simon Lemnius— Made the second draught of my Note to the Cabinet Ministry— Read further after dinner in Gillies. Mrs: Brown and her daughters passed the Evening with us.— Lord Talbot and Mr: Sloper— Dr: Brown and his son.

28. Continue employed as for sometime past.— It was this day that the company was here mentioned as of yesterday.— Last Evening I read the wife of Bath’s prologue and tale in Chaucer and compared the last with Dryden’s revival of it— The tale is a favourite with most Nations— Voltaire has told it under the title of la fée Urgèla, ou ce qui plait aux dames.

Day. The morning as of the last month— But have spent during this many evenings at home reading Gillies and Chaucer.— I finished the 4th: and last volume of the Grecian History this day.— It contains the history of Philip and Alexander of Macedon, and is more interesting than the preceding volumes.— Yet it is dry and insipid compared with the natural spirit of the subject. I was not before aware, that Macedon was not properly considered as a part of Greece.
